So we have another five years to really get to the end of this and hopefully close that gap. And that is our aim.There are certainly many, many moments of frustration. There is no doubt about that. Not just with the Northern Territory, there are other jurisdictions that we continually need to work with.But the NT specifically, I’ve reached out directly to the chief minister, I have raised directly the concerns around the incarceration rates, but also the deaths in custody that we’ve had in the last 12 months, really, in the NT in particular. items.title: Australia news LIVE: Angus Taylor to challenge Sussan Ley for Liberal Party leadership tomorrow; Israeli President arrives in Melbourne
items.standfirst: Follow along as we bring you the latest live news updates from Australia and beyond.
items.content: Follow along as we bring you the latest live news updates from Australia and beyond.

items.title: On Sussan Ley’s possible final day of leadership, Angus Taylor was all smiles – even through a 75-minute roasting | Josh Butler
items.standfirst: Taylor’s clumsy challenge looks likely to succeed on Friday although the aspiring opposition leader hasn’t outlined any real alternative courseFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe butt of every Labor joke all week, Angus Taylor looked happier and more engaged in question time than he has all term.As the gags about his political greatest hits rained down – “well done Angus”, the forged Clover Moore documents, his ineffectual tilt as shadow treasurer – Taylor was smiley and chatty. He spent question time looking down from his new perch on the backbench, a few rows back from Sussan Ley’s spot at the dispatch box, no doubt looking forward to taking her chair before long. Continue reading...

items.title: Angus Taylor will challenge for the Liberal leadership – but who will be the deputy?

items.title: Rebel Queensland LNP MP urges colleagues to ‘put on the full armour of God’ and speak against abortion
items.standfirst: Nigel Dalton says he sought to redeem himself ‘in the eyes of God’ by crossing the floor in an attempt to overturn the LNP’s abortion debate gag orderFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe rebel Liberal National party Queensland MP Nigel Dalton, who earlier this week defied the state’s premier, David Crisafulli, over the abortion law debate, has encouraged others “to put on the full armour of God” and speak out on the issue.In an interview posted on YouTube, Dalton told the anti-abortion activist Joanna Howe his “history with anti-abortion has been probably 30-odd years in the making”. items.title: The Libspill is on: Taylor v Ley set for Liberal leadership showdown on Friday morning - podcast

Political editor Tom McIllroy speaks to Reged Ahmad about why Taylor is making his move now, whether he has the numbers to win, and what it all means for the future direction of the CoalitionRead more: Continue reading...

items.title: Taylor quits frontbench to set up Liberal leadership battle with Ley
items.standfirst: Angus Taylor has resigned from the Coalition frontbench, setting up a contest to replace Sussan Ley as the Liberal Party leader.
items.content: Angus Taylor has resigned from the Coalition frontbench, setting up a contest to replace Sussan Ley as the Liberal Party leader. Taylor met with Ley last night and released a resignation letter saying the party was weaker than it had ever been and needed a change in leadership."I've tendered my resignation as a member of the shadow cabinet," Taylor told reporters at Parliament House.READ MORE: More than a million Aussies in line for major superannuation boost"I've sought to be a constructive member of the leadership team, supported Sussan Ley's leadership in a difficult time when we needed a rebuild of the party."But we can't mince words. The Liberal Party is at the worst position it has been since 1944, when the party was formed. That is a confronting reality and we cannot ignore it."I don't believe Sussan Ley is in a position to be able to lead the party, as it needs to be led from here."Taking a small number of questions, he refused to go into details about timing for a party room vote to spill the leadership and elect a new leader.Asked what he would do differently from Ley, Taylor said his focus would be on "restoring our standard of living and protecting our way of life"."That's what Australians want to see. You'll hear you'll hear more from me and others, I'm sure, in the coming days," he said.READ MORE: One Nation's popularity is surging. But what does Pauline Hanson's party actually stand for?Taylor said the tendering of his resignation had been delayed because it was important not to interrupt Israeli President Isaac Herzog's visit to Parliament House. Ley is yet to comment.This morning Liberal frontbencher Claire Chandler resigned from Ley's shadow ministry. Other Liberal frontbenchers are expected to follow.However, other key Liberals have told 9News Taylor's numbers for victory are not assured.Ley, who met with Israeli President Isaac Herzog inside Parliament House yesterday, is the first woman to lead the Liberal Party after edging out Taylor in a party room ballot in May.Moderate Liberal MP Tim Wilson declined to give his outright backing when asked if he would continue to support Ley in a leadership vote."Well, as I've said, if you want loyalty, you have to show loyalty, and I believe in loyalty very much as a foundation for trust," he told ABC's 7.30."And off the back of that, I will then be going on, of course, as processes go on, to make sure that I'm making the decision in the best interests of the Liberal Party."But I've said that, you know, I support the leader."He did not rule out backing Taylor in a leadership contest.Nine national affairs editor Andrew Probyn said many Liberals were angry that Ley hadn't had a fair crack at the leadership while others were prepared to back Taylor but suspected he didn't have what it took to take on Labor."What was striking about Angus Taylor tonight was that he didn't announce any new policy direction at this stage, the main policy is simply that he wants to be leader now," Probyn said tonight."That may change tomorrow. Perhaps he'll give his colleagues a better pitch, but for liberals voting in a leadership ballot, the biggest question is whether they stick with Sussan Ley."I'm told that the numbers remain tight, neither side entirely confident, but even Lee's supporters want this damaging squabble sorted out one way or the other."Labor MPs were already laying into Taylor during question time today."Just when we thought that they couldn't go any lower on economic credibility, the member for Hume says, 'Hold my chardonnay'," Treasurer Jim Chalmers said."He is a living, breathing reminder that the Liberal Party has become the party of higher income taxes, higher deficits and higher debt. He goes months without asking questions in this place. "Those opposite should ask themselves if they really want him to do to their party this term what he did to their economic credibility last term."A leadership spill has been looming after a tumultuous period for the Liberals.The Coalition split last month when three Nationals senators voted against the government's hate groups bill and were sacked from the frontbench.Although the parties have since come back together, there have been growing concerns that One Nation has overtaken the Liberals in opinion polls and Ley's personal preferred prime minister polls have tanked.The latest Newspoll released on Monday saw the Coalition's primary vote slide to 18 per cent, now behind Labor at 33 per cent and One Nation on 27 per cent. The Liberal primary vote is just 15 per cent.Taylor, who had been the shadow defence spokesperson and formerly shadow treasurer, has emerged as the frontrunner to replace Ley in the event of a spill after fellow conservative Andrew Hastie withdrew from contention late last month.NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here

clusters.title: Man miraculously found alive after almost four days missing in rugged bushland
clusters.neutral_headline: Man miraculously found alive after almost four days missing in rugged bushland
bullet_summary: A man has been found alive after surviving almost four days without any food, water or supplies in rugged bushland in Tasmania
Police said he was able to "keep himself busy" without food, water and supplies
Police say he has been found alive at the bottom of a steep incline

items.title: Man miraculously found alive after almost four days missing in rugged bushland
items.standfirst: A man has been found alive after surviving almost four days without any food, water or supplies in rugged bushland in Tasmania.
items.content: A man has been found alive after surviving almost four days without any food, water or supplies in rugged bushland in Tasmania.

items.title: Man miraculously found alive after almost four days missing in rugged bushland
items.standfirst: Police said he was able to "keep himself busy" without food, water and supplies.
items.content: A man has been found alive after surviving almost four days without any food, water or supplies in rugged bushland in Tasmania.Corey Chugg was with a friend at Mt Barrow, north-east of Launceston, on Sunday night when the pair became separated.The 32-year-old became lost and has been missing since with police holding concerns for his safety.READ MORE: Reason why COVID vaccine caused serious blood clots revealedA massive search and rescue team, including emergency services, ATVs, drones and a helicopter, has been scouring the area since Sunday.Earlier today, crews found him at the bottom of a steep incline near a creek on the edge of the known search area."They walked along the usual path, called out to Mr Chugg, who has replied and said hello and who he was and was incredibly grateful to be found," Inspector Aleena Crack said."I've spoken to the rescuers themselves, and they were incredibly pleased and very happy."It's always a great relief when you find somebody alive and well, much better than any alternative outcome and everyone is really happy with how it's gone today."READ MORE: Floodwaters inundate Aussie town, multiple residents rescuedConditions have been favourable over the past few days, with temperatures around the mid-teens to mid-20s and no rainfall recorded. But temperatures dropped last night with a low of 7.7 degrees recorded about 6.30am."Thankfully, there was water around, and he's been able to keep himself busy and occupied and as well as possible," Crack said. Chugg was winched to safety and able to speak with emergency services. He received a medical assessment before being taken to the hospital.He is suffering from some exposure-related illness and has a foot injury, but the extent of his physical condition is unknown at this stage.READ MORE: Iconic Australian retailer collapses into receivership Police have contacted his family to let them know he has been found alive. They will be speaking to him after he recovers to understand how he became lost. NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here

clusters.title: Kids young as 10 to be fitted with ankle monitors in Queensland
clusters.neutral_headline: Kids young as 10 to be fitted with ankle monitors in Queensland

items.title: Kids young as 10 to be fitted with ankle monitors in Queensland
items.standfirst: Legislation passed today will mean courts can impose a GPS device as a bail condition for youth offenders aged 10 and 17, including first-time offenders.
items.content: A controversial trial to which allowed authorities to fit young offenders on bail with ankle monitors has been made permanent in Queensland.Bailed children as young as 10 can be tracked 24/7 using GPS ankle bracelets under new youth bail monitoring laws passed in the state.A 2021 trial under the Labor government, which placed the devices on repeat youth offenders aged 15 to 18, was met with mixed results.READ MORE: Suspect identified as Canada reels from school mass shootingThe Crisafulli government has claimed only four youth offenders were fitted with the device in the first year.Legislation passed today will mean courts can impose a GPS device as a bail condition for youth offenders aged 10 and 17, including first-time offenders.Youth Justice and Victim Support Minister Laura Gerber said the tough bail laws would decrease offending."The former Labor government continuously weakened youth crime laws, made detention a last resort, abolished breach of bail as an offence and created a generation of serious repeat offenders," Gerber said. "By putting more GPS trackers on youth offenders on bail, alongside intensive support services, we will reduce reoffending, have fewer victims of crime and safer communities."The devices have been found to reduce reoffending by 24 per cent, according to Gerber. READ MORE: Police seek man over alleged hoax calls to Queensland lifeguardsYouth advocates were scathing of the new laws in a parliamentary hearing last month. "With 10 to 14 year olds, there is no evidence anywhere that EMDs will be at all productive for this cohort," Youth Advocacy Centre chief executive Katherine Hayes said."Sixty per cent of these young people, home is not a safe place for them, and confining them to an unsafe space is probably one of the worst things we can do," PeakCare chief executive Tom Allsop said.Queensland Family and Child Commission Commissioner Natalie Lewis also criticised the move."It violates children's rights, it ignores what science tells us about child development and it contradicts everything we know about effective youth justice," Lewis said.Despite the backlash, the bill will pass when parliament resumes with the support of youth crime victims."The electronic monitoring devices is just another tool that is available to the courts," Voice for Victims advocate Trudy Reading said.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Children as young as 10 on bail to be fitted with ankle bracelets in Queensland
items.standfirst: Magistrates will now be able to order children as young as 10 to wear electronic monitoring devices as a bail condition.
items.content: Magistrates will now be able to order children as young as 10 to wear electronic monitoring devices as a bail condition.

clusters.title: Floodwaters inundate Aussie town, multiple residents rescued
clusters.neutral_headline: Floodwaters inundate Aussie town, multiple residents rescued

items.title: Floodwaters inundate Aussie town, multiple residents rescued
items.standfirst: Emergency services were forced to rescue multiple people this morning after flash flooding cut off residents in Alice Springs following a heavy downpour overnight.
items.content: Emergency services had to rescue multiple people this morning after flash flooding cut off residents in Alice Springs following a heavy downpour overnight.The deluge cut off several roads and low-level causeways this morning, leaving some residents unable to go to work or school.Northern Territory Police, Fire and Emergency Services issued an emergency warning due to flooding around the Todd River early this morning, but this warning was later downgraded to a watch and act warning. READ MORE: Audio of 'extraordinary' boy's Triple Zero call after 4km swimNT Police Commissioner Martin Dole said emergency services were called to rescue multiple people today, including a resident who became stuck in a tree."There's still a lady in a tree i n Heavitree Gap with arrangements being made to rescue her," Dole said."Another lady was pulled out of floodwaters in The Gap." We pulled a gentleman out of the river on the Wills Terrace Causeway that was trapped in floodwaters."Three people were rescued off the roof of a car on the Stephens Causeway after that vehicle became stuck on the bridge."Dole said a security guard was also rescued after he was cut off by floodwaters in the town and was unable to get back across a river.Local state MP Joshua Burgoyne said schools were open today but residents should only travel to schools "if it is safe to do so"." There are some teachers, some educators, who are unable to get into school today, so they will be operating at a changed capacity," Burgoyne said." You will not be turned away from school if you arrive there this morning with your children, but obviously if you are able to keep your kids home, that will help the education department."READ MORE: One state driving the biggest spike in first home buyer loans in years Residents have been urged to monitor the SecureNT website for the latest weather warnings and advice. " We'd encourage people to stay aware of SecureNT for the latest advice in relation to weather warnings and listen to the advice that's going out," Dole said.Locals have also been urged not to drive through floodwaters. "If you have to wait an hour to get through a flooded river, please wait," Burgoyne said."If it's flooded, forget it, the message could not be clearer."Please everyone in Alice Springs and surrounding areas, stay safe."NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here
